Column Comment.0: SYSTEM IDENTIFIER: A unique identifier for a data storage system, such as adatabase or XML schema.
Column Comment.1: TABLE NAME: The name of the table within the schema.
Column Comment.2: COLUMN NAME: Name of the column within a specific table found in the PPDMschema
Column Comment.3: COLUMN ALIAS IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for a column alias.
Column Comment.4: ABBREVIATION: Abbreviation used for reference type or code.
Column Comment.5: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether this row of data is currently eitheractive / valid (Y) or inactive / invalid (N).
Column Comment.6: ALIAS NAME: the name that is to be used as the alias.
Column Comment.7: ALIAS REASON TYPE: This reference table describes the purpose or reason for agiven alias. For example a well alias may be assigned to the well because of a namechange or amendment to the identifier. A business associate alias may be created asa result of a merger or name change.
Column Comment.8: SHORT NAME: A short name given to an alias.
Column Comment.9: ALIAS TYPE: This reference table describes the type of alias. For example a wellmay be assigned a government alias, contract alias or project alias. Businessassociates may be assigned a stock exchange symbol alias. Table names may havepublic or private synonyms.
Column Comment.10: AMENDED DATE: the date on which a name has been ammended. Often, this isused for official or legal changes to a name.
Column Comment.11: CREATED DATE: The date on which the alias was first created. This date maypreceed the ammendment date, in the event that the ammended date refers to aformal registration event.
Column Comment.12: EFFECTIVE DATE: the date that this alias came into effect or was loaded into thesystem.
Column Comment.13: EXPIRY DATE: the date on which this row of data is no longer in effect from abusiness perspective.
Column Comment.14: LANGUAGE: The form of a means of communicating ideas or feelings by the use ofconventionalized signs, sounds, gestures, or marks having understood meanings.Usually the language used in a document, proceding, process or appllication.
Column Comment.15: ORIGINAL INDICATOR: A y/n flag indicating that this alias is the original one firstassigned to a business object.
Column Comment.16: ALIAS OWNER: the unique identifier for the business associate who is the owner ofthis alias.
Column Comment.17: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.18: PREFERRED INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether this alias is preferred forgeneral use.
Column Comment.19: REASON DESCRIPTION: A narrative explanation about the alias being used.
Column Comment.20: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data.
Column Comment.21: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.22: SOURCE DOCUMENT: References the document where this alias has been given.Documents may be published, internal references, journals etc.
Column Comment.23: STRUCK OFF DATE: Date on which the legal name was struck from corporateregistry and is no longer used.
Column Comment.24: APPLICATION NAME: Unique name or identifier for a software application or suite ofapplications that uses a specific alias or synonym.
Column Comment.25: USE RULE: A business rule describing how and where the alias is to be used.
Column Comment.26: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.27: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.28: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.29: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.30: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.31: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.32: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
